stem: A 7-year-old child presents with 'tea-colored' urine, periorbital edema, and a BP of 132/88. His mother notes he had a sore throat about 10 days ago. Complete the bowtie to guide management.

actions.text: Monitor BP every 4 hours and manage hypertension

rationale.correct: APSGN follows a strep infection. Signs: Hematuria (tea-colored), HTN, and mild/moderate edema. Priority is managing the hypertension and fluid overload. Monitoring Focus: Weight (fluid status) and Urine changes.
rationale.incorrect: High protein is not needed and can strain kidneys. Heparin is for clots. Unlike nephrotic syndrome, massive proteinuria is not the hallmark, so high protein isn't the fix.

reviewUnits.heading: Acute Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis â€” Pathophysiology & Recognition
reviewUnits.body: APSGN follows a strep infection. Signs: Hematuria (tea-colored), HTN, and mild/moderate edema. Priority is managing the hypertension and fluid overload. Monitoring Focus: Weight (fluid status) and Urine changes. The most important parameter to monitor in acute glomerulonephritis is blood pressure (due to encephalopathy risk).

reviewUnits.heading: Testing Trap â€” APSGN vs Nephrotic
reviewUnits.body: APSGN = HTN + Blood. Nephrotic = No HTN + Massive Protein/Edema.

reviewUnits.heading: Priority Interventions for Acute Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis
reviewUnits.body: The priority nursing interventions are: Monitor BP every 4 hours and manage hypertension; Restrict sodium and fluid intake. Monitor: Daily weight and I&O; Urine characteristics (color/blood). High protein is not needed and can strain kidneys. Heparin is for clots. Unlike nephrotic syndrome, massive proteinuria is not the hallmark, so high protein isn't the fix.
